moves.1. e4: Here's a mini in from the fast ladder just finished this morning.  There is quite a disparity in ratings, and White deviates pretty early, but starts off with a line that Kasparov has used against the Accelerated Dragon.
moves.1... c5: Having played 1...e5 for about 10 years and 1...e6 for 3 years, I have become a lifelong devotee of the Sicilian.
moves.2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4: Most lower rated players will try and keep the position closed, kudos to my opponent for the fighting spirit.
moves.5. Nc3: This is the move which I love to see as it most often is followed by the Yugoslav attack setup.  Again, Kudos to my opponent for this.
moves.5... Bg7 6. Nxc6: The moment of truth!  White typically plays 6. Be3 Nf6; 7. Bc4, with the standard Yugo setup.  This move gives Black extra control over d5, but Kasparov has used it on occasion.
moves.6... bxc6: 6...dc, allowing the queen trade is playable, but I prefer to open the b-file to utilize by dark-squared bishop to the max.
moves.7. Bc4: White is still playing quite aggressively, luckily, I am still in my preparation.
moves.8. Be3: White never does get castled in this game and so I like 8. 0-0 here.  This removes any potential rook sac ideas on b2 should white play Rb1 to defend his queenside.
moves.9. Qf3: I expected 9. Bd4, as most players are keen to swap the black fianchetto bishop.  As most one move threats, it is easily dealt with as I kick off my queenside advantage.
moves.9... d5: Anticipating 10. Bb3 Rxb3; 11. axb3 d4, with a slight advantage to black.  Instead White cedes the initiative to me and unnecessarily, a piece.
moves.10. exd5: The open b-file and uncastled king are not good positional factors for white.
moves.10... Rxb2: Hanging the knight and creating a whole series of problems for white.
moves.11. dxc6: I saw a way to limit Blacks advantage with 11. 0-0 as 11...Bxc3 is a blunder after 12. d6, handing the initiative to white.  So after 11. 0-0 Rb4; 12. d6 ed, the f7-pawn is protected twice, but it looks like White's best chance.
moves.11... Bxc3+: Now there is no hope for the White monarch.
moves.12. Kf1: All other moves keep the White king close to the center.
moves.12... Nf6: Blocking the White attack on f7 and developing.
moves.13. Bg5: Uncovering an attack on the c3-bishop.
moves.13... Be5: I didnt want to play Bd4 as I wanted to threaten the c2- pawn without allowing Qd3.
moves.14. Re1: Setting up a tactic on the e-file, so I decide to neutralize it with...
moves.14... O-O 15. g3: White tries to make some room for the king and link his rooks.  The position is still losing due to material and better coordination of the black pieces.
moves.16. Bb3: Forcing me off the second rank, but I do get another pawn!
moves.16... Rxc6 17. Ba4: Harassing my rook, but it only allows me to setup the final combination.
moves.17... Rc3: Targeting the queen, but also with an eye on the white king.  Already I am seeing a potential sacrifice on g3.
moves.18... Bh3+: The most forcing moves get analysed first and here I saw huge material had to be given up to stave off mate.
moves.19... Bd4: Setting up the g3 sacrifice, but my opponent doesnt see it.

opening: Sicilian (B35), accelerated fianchetto, modern variation with Bc4
